subsection.name: Description
subsection.div: Checks that a specified pattern matches across multiple lines in any file type.
subsection.p: Rationale: This check can be used to when the regular expression can be span multiple lines.

tr.td: Specify the file extensions of the files to process.
Specify the format of the regular expression to match.
Control whether to ignore case when searching.
Control whether to match expressions across multiple lines.
Specify the maximum number of matches required in each file.
Specify the message which is used to notify about violations, if empty then default (hard-coded) message is used.
Specify the minimum number of matches required in each file.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To run the check with its default configuration (no matches will be):
To configure the check to find calls to print to the console:
To configure the check to match text that spans multiple lines, like normal code in a Java file:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="RegexpMultiline"> <property name="matchAcrossLines" value="true"/> <property name="format" value="System\.out.*?print\("/> </module> </module>

subsection.p: Note: Beware of the greedy regular expression used in the above example. .* will match as much as possible and not produce multiple violations in the file if multiple groups of lines could match the expression. To prevent an expression being too greedy, avoid overusing matching all text or allow it to be optional, like .*?. Changing the example expression to not be greedy will allow multiple violations in the example to be found in the same file.
To configure the check to match a maximum of three test strings:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="RegexpMultiline"> <property name="format" value="Test #[0-9]+:[A-Za-z ]+"/> <property name="ignoreCase" value="true"/> <property name="maximum" value="3"/> </module> </module>

subsection.p: To configure the check to match a minimum of two test strings:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="RegexpMultiline"> <property name="format" value="Test #[0-9]+:[A-Za-z ]+"/> <property name="minimum" value="2"/> </module> </module>

subsection.p: To configure the check to restrict an empty file:

pre.code: <module name="Checker"> <module name="RegexpMultiline"> <property name="format" value="^\s*$" /> <property name="matchAcrossLines" value="true" /> <property name="message" value="Empty file is not allowed" /> </module> </module>

subsection.p: Example of violation from the above config:
subsection.source: /var/tmp/Test.java // violation, a file must not be empty.

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.
